contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox chess player |name = Louis de La Bourdonnais |image= Louisdelabourdonnais.jpg |birthname = Louis-Charles Mahé de La Bourdonnais |country = France |birth_date = 1795 |birth_place = France |death_date = 1840 (aged 44 or 45) |death_place = |title = |worldchampion = 1821–40 (Unofficial) |womensworldchampion = |rating = |peakrating = }} '''Louis-Charles Mahé de La Bourdonnais''' (1795–1840) was a [[France|French]] [[chess master]], possibly the strongest player in the early 19th century. == Early life == La Bourdonnais was born on the island of La [[Réunion]] in the Indian Ocean in 1795. He learned chess in 1814 and began to take the game seriously in 1818, when he regularly played at the [[Café de la Régence]].<ref>The Oxford Companion to Chess – David Hooper and Kenneth Whyld (1992) p. 56</ref> He took lessons from [[Jacques François Mouret]], his first teacher,<ref>[http://books.google.it/books?id=gzICAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA1&dq=&as_brr=1#v=onepage&q=mouret&f=false ''La Palamède'' edited by St. Amaint (1847) p. 211]</ref> and within two years he became one of the best players of the ''Café''. La Bourdonnais was forced to earn his living as a professional chess player after squandering his fortune on ill-advised land deals. == Unofficial World Chess Champion == {{main|La Bourdonnais - McDonnell chess matches}} La Bourdonnais was considered to be the unofficial [[World Chess Champion]] (there was no official title at the time) from 1821—when he became able to beat his chess teacher [[Alexandre Deschapelles]]—until his death in 1840. The most famous match series, indeed considered as the world championship, was the series against [[Alexander McDonnell]] in 1834. == Death == He died penniless in London in 1840, having been forced to sell all of his possessions, including his clothes, to satisfy his creditors. [[George Walker (chess player)|George Walker]] arranged to have him buried just a stone's throw away from his old rival [[Alexander McDonnell]] in London's [[Kensal Green Cemetery]].<ref>[[Philip W. Sergeant]], ''A Century of British Chess'', David McKay, 1934, p. 39.</ref><ref>{{cite book | last =Walker | first =George | authorlink =George Walker (chess player) | coauthors = | title =Chess and Chess-Players | publisher =C. J. Skeet | year =1850 | location =London | pages = | url = | doi = | isbn = }}</ref> He was the grandson of [[Bertrand-François Mahé de La Bourdonnais]]. == Notable games == {{Chess diagram|= | tright |'''McDonnell–La Bourdonnais, 1834''' |= 8 | | | |bd| | |rd|kd|= 7 | | | |pl| | |pd|pd|= 6 | | | | | | | | |= 5 |pd| | | | | | | |= 4 | | | | | | | | |= 3 | | |ql| | | | | |= 2 |pl| | |pd|pd|pd|pl|pl|= 1 | | | |rl| | | |kl|= a b c d e f g h | Final position after Black's 37...e2 }} {{algebraic notation|pos=egright}} * [http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1001165 Alexander McDonnell vs Louis-Charles Mahé de La Bourdonnais, 16, London 1834, Sicilian Defense: Old Sicilian.
